abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is assessed as
            highly satisfactory, and sustainability is highly likely,
            with high institutional development impacts. Lessons drawn
            from the project identify a generally positive grant
            administration by the local, non-governmental agency, the
            Technology Development Foundation (TDF), whose performance
            was well regarded, and supported by confident Turkish
            companies, who responded appropriately to TDF's
            supervision of the fund supporting the ozone depleting
            substances (ODS) phase-out. Nonetheless, inter-agency
            coordination delays in reaching a policy consensus were
            higher than expected, as were the delays in the development
            of policy consensus with business (although finally highly
            successful) on the National Ozone Plan. This lead to
            inadequate allocation of funds to public, and industry
            awareness campaigns, because of higher media costs than
            previously estimated in the project. Furthermore, the
            project evaluation process of the Montreal Protocol (MP)
            Executive Committee is found to be very slow, based on
            organizations' complaints that long periods elapse,
            before their proposals can be even considered, and, in some
            cases, the incomplete MP guidelines by which to evaluate
            proposals, leads to delays, such as the approval of
            Turkey's pending Refrigeration Plan, meaning an
            increase of 2000 ODS imports by 56 tons.
